<a href="https://christopher-cloos.com/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=TMB&utm_campaign=TMB" style="border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank" class=""><img alt="Christopher Cloos" style="width:100%;max-width: 160px; display: inline; vertical-align: middle;" width="160" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL2NvbXBhbnkvbG9nby8yNC8xNTc2MDc3MTc1LTE1NjA3NzMzNTEuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0IjoiY29tZXQtbW9ybmluZ2JyZXciLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ=="></a>
</th>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good Saturday morning. </strong>We're doing something a little different today because...pandemic.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s clear that until a vaccine arrives in 2021 earliest, there is no life <em>post</em>-coronavirus—there's only life <em>with </em>coronavirus. It's up to us to understand a) to what extent our lives will change and b) how we can use this shock to the system to remake our world for the better. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Saturday mornings, the Brew writers will guide you through our “new normal” by exploring the long-term effects of COVID-19 on one topic or industry. Today’s theme: <strong style="color:#000"><em>the future of cities</em></strong>. We hope you enjoy/learn something, and as always reply with your thoughts. </p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CITIES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/24/cities-will-eventually-return-life-theyll-look-different?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Don’t Call It a Comeback
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A rebuilt city" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTEvYV9yZWJ1aWx0X2NpdHkuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When cities come back to life, they might have a more familiar taste than you expect—like Dippin' Dots. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That might sound a little crazy. Cities are powered by kinetic energy: people bumping into each other on the street, cramming into concert venues and sports stadiums, sitting down at restaurants. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Without those opportunities, a city will lose its allure. No wonder all the <a href="https://thecity.nyc/2020/04/garbage-pickups-tell-tale-of-two-cities-as-manhattan-shrinks.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rich people</a> have left for the Hamptons—you get 10x the space but Seamless tastes the same anywhere. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yet, cities have proven to be one of the most enduring of humanity’s inventions. They’ve withstood <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/04/06/pandemics-and-the-shape-of-human-history?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pandemics</a>, <a href="https://www.brookings.edu/research/how-covid-19-will-change-the-nations-long-term-economic-trends-brookings-metro/#5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">recessions</a>, and the <a href="https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2013/11/the-myth-of-technology-and-the-death-of-distance-098982?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">internet age</a>. When faced with adversity, cities have rebuilt themselves to adapt, all while sticking with their most successful traits: density, jobs, and rich cultural life.  </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">So what can we expect? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The coronavirus pandemic strikes at the heart of a city’s engine: its social interactions. As cities ease lockdowns, they’ll have to ensure those face-to-face experiences can occur while keeping everyone healthy.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Transportation: </strong>Public transportation is an essential service, but <a href="https://www.citylab.com/transportation/2020/04/coronavirus-reopen-cities-public-transit-car-free-bike-milan/610360/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">safety measures</a> can be put in place to protect passengers and workers. Think social distance markings and quotas on the number of riders in a single train car. Also, bye-bye Uber Pool. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Retail: </strong>Things will get weird. As hybridization accelerates, a store could be a showroom, a delivery warehouse, a restaurant, and a pop-up market all in one. “A 10-year commercial lease in a single-use building will no longer be standard,” declares Brookings. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Culture: </strong>Expect every event to feel like a Rays game. When sports and theater do return (it may be many, many months), capacity at venues will be limited with chairs left open in between people. And if you thought coughing was frowned upon before...</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Design: </strong>The pandemic showed we need to be prepared to construct new buildings in a hurry and transform others from their original uses. We all saw pictures of those new hospitals in Wuhan going up in two weeks—that was only possible through “<a href="https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/story/2020-04-22/coronavirus-pandemics-architecture-urban-design?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">modular construction</a>,” when a building’s components are prefabricated offsite. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Typical city life we once took for granted will become a real hassle. But we’ll get used to it.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RESHUFFLING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/24/coronavirus-lead-reshuffling-us-city-leaderboard?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
A Tale of 20,000 Cities
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As of 2018, the U.S. contains 19,495 “incorporated places”—cities, towns, and villages. The economic rec(depr)ession unleashed by the coronavirus is already reshuffling the national population and is likely to reshape each of those places differently.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Budgets that depend on income taxes are in trouble</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s a subtweet for the state of Ohio, <a href="https://www.brookings.edu/blog/the-avenue/2020/03/31/when-will-your-city-feel-the-fiscal-impact-of-covid-19/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">which is an outlier</a> in the degree to which it allows city revenues to depend on <span style="text-decoration: line-through;">LeBron James</span> income taxes. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It’s unusual for cities to tax income at all—about 90% of U.S. cities don’t rely on income or wage taxes for funding. But Ohio’s do, and four of the U.S.’ five most income tax-dependent large cities are in the Buckeye state.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Ohio’s income pool is rapidly shrinking, and with it city budgets. Ohio's probable </span><span><a href="https://www.limaohio.com/news/407719/ohio-unemployment-update-weekly-stimulus-payments-start-nearly-17-of-states-workforce-now-unemployed?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jobless rate</a></span><span> is now close to 17%.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The pandemic could also accelerate a trend away from megacities</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Before coronavirus, it was already getting harder to keep young professionals paying $1,400/month for walkup closets in New York and San Francisco. Now that many of us are working remotely and density = danger, there could be a bigger exodus. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>As a counterargument, Brookings's Mark Muro </span><span><a href="https://www.brookings.edu/research/how-covid-19-will-change-the-nations-long-term-economic-trends-brookings-metro/#5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">points out</a></span><span> that "crisis after crisis, the big tech hubs have continued to </span><span><em>increase</em></span><span> their share of the nation’s digital services employment." </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>City guru <a href="https://www.hiringlab.org/2020/04/17/where-job-postings-have-fallen/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Jed Kolko writes</a> the metro areas that will suffer the worst economic slowdowns don’t map directly onto those experiencing the worst outbreaks.</p>

<tr>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SMART CITIES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/24/covid19-future-smart-cities?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Cities Head Back to School
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Delivery bot " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MDkvZGVsaXZlcnlfYm90LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Christian Charisius/picture alliance via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hard times breed innovation and ingenuity. Take 19th century London, where a series of cholera outbreaks taught the city to send its poop <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/26/life-after-coronavirus-pandemic-change-world?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>down</em>stream</a>. Today, COVID-19 could catalyze a wave of smart city upgrades as governments turn to digital infrastructure to guard against future crises. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Cities moving from containment to recovery offer a glimpse of what could come. In Wuhan, China, factory operators <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2020-04-23/wuhan-s-return-to-life-temperature-checks-and-constant-anxiety?sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">register</a> workers’ temperature daily. Returning employees are working alongside more robots than when they left. And to get on a train, residents display app-based “health codes” ranking them by infection risk levels.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Those methods have some privacy advocates bucking like an unbroken colt. But not all solutions have to come at the expense of personal liberty. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In Antwerp, Belgium, workers at Europe’s second-largest port are </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/ce9411c1d93eadedacd73cb402ea7f18?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">testing</a></span><span> bracelets that buzz if workers are too close. They don’t collect data or track movements. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">COVID-19 could also accelerate tech not tied to virus tracking, including...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Automation.</strong></span><span> Fewer hands = less transmission. Companies could </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/04/13/us-retail-robots-working-overtime?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deploy</a></span><span> more robot workers in </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/04/13/us-retail-robots-working-overtime?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">factories/stores</a></span><span>, or autonomous vehicles and drones in </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/03/27/nuro-tusimple-continue-service-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">delivery networks</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Connectivity.</strong></span><span> As more workers go remote, internet connections need to improve outside cities. Governments may </span><span><a href="https://intpolicydigest.org/2020/04/22/after-covid-19-permanent-changes-and-evolution-of-smart-cities/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">double down</a></span><span> on broadband and 5G buildouts. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Reality check:</strong> Smart cities aren’t cheap, and governments are facing severe <a href="https://www.smartcitiesdive.com/news/pandemic-costs-are-blowing-massive-holes-in-cities-budgets/576017/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">budget shortfalls</a> from COVID-19 that could hamstring funding for tech-savvy initiatives.</p>

</a>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TRANSPORTATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/24/covid19-causing-cities-reimagine-purpose-streets?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Cities Are Driven to Keep Cars in Park
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Lone biker in Australia" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MDgvbG9uZV9iaWtlcl9pbl9hdXN0cmFsaWEuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Cameron Spencer/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span style="text-decoration: none;">With stay-at-home orders in effect around the world, check engine lights are getting even less attention than usual. </span><strong style="color:#000"></strong><span style="text-decoration: none;"></span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span style="text-decoration: none;">Historically gridlocked metropolitan areas now look like Daytona International Speedway. </span><span style="text-decoration: none;">Weeks after Massachusetts announced lockdown orders, rush hour traffic </span><span style="text-decoration: none;">moved at an average of </span>62 mph through a busy I-90 corridor,<span style="text-decoration: none;"> <a href="https://qz.com/1827392/where-coronavirus-has-changed-us-driving-habits-the-most/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Quartz found</a>. That’s typically 35 mph. </span><span style="text-decoration: none;"></span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span style="text-decoration: none;">Some city officials are hoping this momentary pause in traffic becomes a permanent red light.  </span></p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Inter Milan </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span style="text-decoration: none;">Milan, Italy, one of Europe’s most polluted cities, is leading the charge to reimagine urban transportation. Its ambitious</span> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/21/milan-seeks-to-prevent-post-crisis-return-of-traffic-pollution?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Strade Aperte plan</a><span style="text-decoration: none;"> intends to transform 22 miles of streets by adding temporary biking lanes, 20 mph speed limits, and wider pavements. </span><strong style="color:#000"> </strong></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span style="text-decoration: none;">Former NYC transportation commissioner Janette Sadik-Khan told The Guardian, “The Milan plan is so important...because it lays out a good playbook for how you can reset your cities now.”</span></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li dir="ltr" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px;list-style-type: disc; text-decoration: none;"><span><span style="text-decoration: none;">Like a good rookie QB, NYC is studying that playbook—the City Council <a href="https://gothamist.com/news/city-council-proposes-essential-workers-bill-rights-includes-hazard-pay-sick-leave?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">introduced a measure</a> that would temporarily open up 75 miles of streets to cyclists and pedestrians.</span></span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>As much as the pedestrianizing of streets is gaining momentum, the reality is that the private car presents the most isolated means of transportation for a nervous public. If <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-08/quick-rebound-in-wuhan-car-sales-give-hope-to-battered-industry?sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Wuhan is any indication</a>, auto sales will quickly bounce back.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
URBAN PLANNING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/24/great-indoors-get-upgrade?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Design Pinterest Isn’t Ready for This
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="SNL sketch" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=375 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/QZsb7H2QVGpbX4FHWA/source.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="SNL sketch" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/QZsb7H2QVGpbX4FHWA/source.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When you’re stuck inside all day, you start to notice the shortcomings of your surroundings—especially in cities with <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/smallest-apartment-for-rent-in-san-francisco-price-photos-2019-9?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">161 sq. ft. studios</a> and mice hyperadapted to your 9–5. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The good news:</strong> COVID-19, in all its terribleness, could usher in improvements to the great indoors.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Introducing: The “Healthy Building” movement</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While planting a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/22/t-magazine/victory-garden-plans.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">victory garden</a> on your sill may make your wall-facing window more #aesthetic, urban planners and architects have more <a href="https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/story/2020-04-22/coronavirus-pandemics-architecture-urban-design?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">practical improvements</a> in mind for homes and offices. Here are a few:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Improved airflow: </strong></span><span>Adding better ventilation and filtration could make hospitals, movie theaters, prisons, and other enclosed spaces healthier places to inhabit. Recycling's great, but not for air.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Dividers: </strong></span><span>Plexiglass-enclosed desks </span><span><a href="https://www.marketplace.org/2020/04/22/how-will-office-spaces-change-after-covid19/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">turned apart</a></span><span> from one another might be the future of the open floor plan office. So basically see-through cubicles. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Hygienic surfaces:</strong></span><span> COVID-19’s ability to survive on surfaces could make antimicrobial polymer and copper alloy surfaces more attractive, writes the LA Times. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And of course, adding <a href="https://www.citylab.com/life/2020/04/apartment-design-balcony-private-outdoor-space-zoning-laws/610162/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more outdoor spaces</a> to urban housing is a top priority for anyone who’s ever used their fire escape as a patio. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Will it actually happen? </strong>We’ll give it a firm “probably,” considering there’s plenty of historical precedent.<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>Outbreaks of the bubonic plague, cholera, smallpox, and the Spanish flu were all followed by advancements in urban planning, like indoor plumbing and waste management.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;">The Austrian studio Precht has designed a park that allows people to hang out outside while <a href="https://www.dezeen.com/2020/04/16/studio-precht-parc-de-la-distance-social-distancing-coronavirus/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">separated by hedges</a>. Smart or just making things too complicated? </p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BREW'S BETS
</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Twenty-seven years of powering through</strong>. Since 1993, The Motley Fool has helped its members navigate their finances through the dot-com bubble, the Housing Crisis, and now COVID-19. <a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/all-in-advert?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=sar-allinalert&aid=9223&paid=9223&waid=9223&source=esamnbwdg0210067&psource=esamnbwdg0210067&wsource=esamnbwdg0210067" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">See what their experts have to say</a>.*</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">If the past few weeks have left you with dark circles under your eyes</strong>, you’re not alone. Port Products’ <a href="https://portproducts.com/pages/hey-morning-brew-get-our-best-selling-eye-gel?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=4%2F25%2F20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">under-eye recovery gel</a>—made with red algae and sea kelp—eliminates those circles, bags, and wrinkles. Take $20 off your first order with the code “MORNINGBREW20” <a href="https://portproducts.com/pages/hey-morning-brew-get-our-best-selling-eye-gel?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=4%2F25%2F20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">at checkout</a>.*</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Hot seat: </strong>You’re used to hearing Kinsey Grant interview impressive people on Morning Brew’s podcast <em data-stringify-type="italic">Business Casual</em><em data-stringify-type="italic">. </em>This week, we’re flipping the script. We kept the “impressive people” part, but Kinsey takes the hot seat to get interviewed by our audio producer. Listen here: <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/kinseygrant_apple" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apple</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/kinseygrant_spotify" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Spotify</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/kinseygrant_all" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">everywhere else</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Weekend date ideas: </strong><a href="https://www.acouplecooks.com/naturally-sweetened-whiskey-sour/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Craft a cocktail</a> over Zoom, virtually <a href="https://people.com/travel/stuck-at-home-these-12-famous-museums-offer-virtual-tours-you-can-take-on-your-couch/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tour a museum</a> together, combine your brain power for a Harry Potter <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSflNxNM0jzbZJjUqOcXkwhGTfii4CM_CA3kCxImbY8c3AABEA/viewform" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">escape room</a>, or see more ideas in our latest issue of <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/the-essentials/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Essentials</a>. </p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nCITIES \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/24/cities-will-eventually-return-life-theyll-look-different?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nDon’t Call It a Comeback\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A rebuilt city\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTEvYV9yZWJ1aWx0X2NpdHkuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen cities come back to life, they might have a more familiar taste than you expect—like Dippin' Dots. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat might sound a little crazy. Cities are powered by kinetic energy: people bumping into each other on the street, cramming into concert venues and sports stadiums, sitting down at restaurants. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWithout those opportunities, a city will lose its allure. No wonder all the \u003ca href=\"https://thecity.nyc/2020/04/garbage-pickups-tell-tale-of-two-cities-as-manhattan-shrinks.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erich people\u003c/a\u003e have left for the Hamptons—you get 10x the space but Seamless tastes the same anywhere. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYet, cities have proven to be one of the most enduring of humanity’s inventions. They’ve withstood \u003ca href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/04/06/pandemics-and-the-shape-of-human-history?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epandemics\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/research/how-covid-19-will-change-the-nations-long-term-economic-trends-brookings-metro/#5?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erecessions\u003c/a\u003e, and the \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2013/11/the-myth-of-technology-and-the-death-of-distance-098982?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einternet age\u003c/a\u003e. When faced with adversity, cities have rebuilt themselves to adapt, all while sticking with their most successful traits: density, jobs, and rich cultural life.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSo what can we expect? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe coronavirus pandemic strikes at the heart of a city’s engine: its social interactions. As cities ease lockdowns, they’ll have to ensure those face-to-face experiences can occur while keeping everyone healthy.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTransportation: \u003c/strong\u003ePublic transportation is an essential service, but \u003ca href=\"https://www.citylab.com/transportation/2020/04/coronavirus-reopen-cities-public-transit-car-free-bike-milan/610360/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esafety measures\u003c/a\u003e can be put in place to protect passengers and workers. Think social distance markings and quotas on the number of riders in a single train car. Also, bye-bye Uber Pool. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eRetail: \u003c/strong\u003eThings will get weird. As hybridization accelerates, a store could be a showroom, a delivery warehouse, a restaurant, and a pop-up market all in one. “A 10-year commercial lease in a single-use building will no longer be standard,” declares Brookings. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eCulture: \u003c/strong\u003eExpect every event to feel like a Rays game. When sports and theater do return (it may be many, many months), capacity at venues will be limited with chairs left open in between people. And if you thought coughing was frowned upon before...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eDesign: \u003c/strong\u003eThe pandemic showed we need to be prepared to construct new buildings in a hurry and transform others from their original uses. We all saw pictures of those new hospitals in Wuhan going up in two weeks—that was only possible through “\u003ca href=\"https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/story/2020-04-22/coronavirus-pandemics-architecture-urban-design?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emodular construction\u003c/a\u003e,” when a building’s components are prefabricated offsite. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eTypical city life we once took for granted will become a real hassle. But we’ll get used to it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs of 2018, the U.S. contains 19,495 “incorporated places”—cities, towns, and villages. The economic rec(depr)ession unleashed by the coronavirus is already reshuffling the national population and is likely to reshape each of those places differently.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBudgets that depend on income taxes are in trouble\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s a subtweet for the state of Ohio, \u003ca href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/blog/the-avenue/2020/03/31/when-will-your-city-feel-the-fiscal-impact-of-covid-19/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewhich is an outlier\u003c/a\u003e in the degree to which it allows city revenues to depend on \u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: line-through;\"\u003eLeBron James\u003c/span\u003e income taxes. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt’s unusual for cities to tax income at all—about 90% of U.S. cities don’t rely on income or wage taxes for funding. But Ohio’s do, and four of the U.S.’ five most income tax-dependent large cities are in the Buckeye state.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOhio’s income pool is rapidly shrinking, and with it city budgets. Ohio's probable \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.limaohio.com/news/407719/ohio-unemployment-update-weekly-stimulus-payments-start-nearly-17-of-states-workforce-now-unemployed?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejobless rate\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e is now close to 17%.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe pandemic could also accelerate a trend away from megacities\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBefore coronavirus, it was already getting harder to keep young professionals paying $1,400/month for walkup closets in New York and San Francisco. Now that many of us are working remotely and density = danger, there could be a bigger exodus. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAs a counterargument, Brookings's Mark Muro \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/research/how-covid-19-will-change-the-nations-long-term-economic-trends-brookings-metro/#5?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epoints out\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e that \"crisis after crisis, the big tech hubs have continued to \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eincrease\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e their share of the nation’s digital services employment.\" \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eCity guru \u003ca href=\"https://www.hiringlab.org/2020/04/17/where-job-postings-have-fallen/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eJed Kolko writes\u003c/a\u003e the metro areas that will suffer the worst economic slowdowns don’t map directly onto collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHard times breed innovation and ingenuity. Take 19th century London, where a series of cholera outbreaks taught the city to send its poop \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/26/life-after-coronavirus-pandemic-change-world?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003edown\u003c/em\u003estream\u003c/a\u003e. Today, COVID-19 could catalyze a wave of smart city upgrades as governments turn to digital infrastructure to guard against future crises. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCities moving from containment to recovery offer a glimpse of what could come. In Wuhan, China, factory operators \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2020-04-23/wuhan-s-return-to-life-temperature-checks-and-constant-anxiety?sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eregister\u003c/a\u003e workers’ temperature daily. Returning employees are working alongside more robots than when they left. And to get on a train, residents display app-based “health codes” ranking them by infection risk levels.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThose methods have some privacy advocates bucking like an unbroken colt. But not all solutions have to come at the expense of personal liberty. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIn Antwerp, Belgium, workers at Europe’s second-largest port are \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/ce9411c1d93eadedacd73cb402ea7f18?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etesting\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e bracelets that buzz if workers are too close. They don’t collect data or track movements. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCOVID-19 could also accelerate tech not tied to virus tracking, including...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAutomation.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Fewer hands = less transmission. Companies could \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/04/13/us-retail-robots-working-overtime?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeploy\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e more robot workers in \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/04/13/us-retail-robots-working-overtime?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efactories/stores\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, or autonomous vehicles and drones in \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/03/27/nuro-tusimple-continue-service-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edelivery networks\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eConnectivity.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e As more workers go remote, internet connections need to improve outside cities. Governments may \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://intpolicydigest.org/2020/04/22/after-covid-19-permanent-changes-and-evolution-of-smart-cities/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edouble down\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e on broadband and 5G buildouts. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eReality style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eCameron Spencer/Getty collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003eWith stay-at-home orders in effect around the world, check engine lights are getting even less attention than usual. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003eHistorically gridlocked metropolitan areas now look like Daytona International Speedway. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003eWeeks after Massachusetts announced lockdown orders, rush hour traffic \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003emoved at an average of \u003c/span\u003e62 mph through a busy I-90 corridor,\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://qz.com/1827392/where-coronavirus-has-changed-us-driving-habits-the-most/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eQuartz found\u003c/a\u003e. That’s typically 35 mph. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003eSome city officials are hoping this momentary pause in traffic becomes a permanent red light.  \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eInter Milan \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003eMilan, Italy, one of Europe’s most polluted cities, is leading the charge to reimagine urban transportation. Its ambitious\u003c/span\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/21/milan-seeks-to-prevent-post-crisis-return-of-traffic-pollution?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eStrade Aperte plan\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003e intends to transform 22 miles of streets by adding temporary biking lanes, 20 mph speed limits, and wider pavements. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003eFormer NYC transportation commissioner Janette Sadik-Khan told The Guardian, “The Milan plan is so important...because it lays out a good playbook for how you can reset your cities now.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli dir=\"ltr\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px;list-style-type: disc; text-decoration: none;\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: none;\"\u003eLike a good rookie QB, NYC is studying that playbook—the City Council \u003ca href=\"https://gothamist.com/news/city-council-proposes-essential-workers-bill-rights-includes-hazard-pay-sick-leave?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eintroduced a measure\u003c/a\u003e that would temporarily open up 75 miles of streets to cyclists and pedestrians.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eAs much as the pedestrianizing of streets is gaining momentum, the reality is that the private car presents the most isolated means of transportation for a nervous public. If \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-08/quick-rebound-in-wuhan-car-sales-give-hope-to-battered-industry?sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWuhan is any indication\u003c/a\u003e, auto sales will quickly bounce
